message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms are consistent with Hirschsprung’s disease, in which there is an absence of the Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the bowel wall. The other options do not explain the absence of plexi in the bowel wall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The infant’s symptoms suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, which is a congenital condition where there is a lack of ganglion cells in the colon resulting in bowel obstruction. The absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the biopsy confirms the diagnosis. None of the other options fit the symptoms presented.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is characterized by the absence of nerves in the distal part of the colon and rectum. The absence of Meissner's and Auerbach's plexi in the biopsy confirms the diagnosis. The other options do not match the symptoms presented, as they do not involve the absence of nerves in the bowel wall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of Meissner's and Auerbach's plexi indicates Hirschsprung's disease, which is a developmental disorder of the enteric nervous system. The other options do not involve the absence of these plexi.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting, inability to pass meconium, and distended abdomen are all consistent with Hirschsprung’s disease, which is characterized by a lack of ganglion cells in the bowel wall, leading to obstruction and dilation of the colon. None of the other options presented include this specific feature.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting, inability to pass meconium, and distended abdomen strongly suggest Hirschsprung's disease, which is characterized by the absence of Meissner's and Auerbach's plexi in the effected bowel segments. The other options are not associated with this condition.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting and inability to pass meconium are classic signs of Hirschsprung’s disease, which is caused by the absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the bowel wall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of bilious vomiting, failure to pass meconium, and distended abdomen are typical of Hirschsprung's disease, which is a congenital disorder characterized by the absence of ganglion cells in the distal part of the colon. The absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the biopsy supports this diagnosis. The other options are not typically associated with these symptoms or biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and biopsy findings suggest Hirschsprung’s disease, a congenital disorder where there is a lack of ganglion cells in the colon resulting in bowel obstruction and impaired motility. The other options do not fit the symptoms and biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the absence of Meissner’s and Auerbach’s plexi in the bowel wall, inability to pass meconium, and distended abdomen are all indicative of Hirschsprung’s disease, which is a disorder of the colon and is caused by the absence of ganglia in the intestinal wall. The other options are less likely to present with these symptoms.
